newsitem.title: GERMANY: IG Metall proposes new part-time work model.
newsitem.headline: IG Metall proposes new part-time work model.

text.p: German engineering trade union IG Metall, locked in wider wage talks with employers, said on Tuesday it had proposed a new system for increasing part-time work available to employees approaching pension age.
IG Metall deputy chairman Walter Riester told a news briefing the proposal was a measure aimed at increasing employment in the metal and engineering sector.

Under the proposal, employees would get 85 percent of their net wages for the last 10 years of their working life until age 65. In return, they would work five years of that full-time and the rest at an agreed part-time rate.
The system would extend the current German practice of employees working part-time for the last five years before their pensionable age.
Riester said that with envisaged state funding for the scheme, such a system would be "significantly cheaper" than the current system.
But the Gesamtmetall employers' federation gave the scheme a cool response. In a statement it said that such a contractual part-time work system could only work voluntarily.
